description: Minor Material Amendment (Section 73) for variation of conditions 26 (Drawing Numbers), 41 (Cycle Parking), 47 (Non-residential floor space) pursuant to ref (164694FUL) dated 01/09/2017 for phased redevelopment comprising a residential-led mixed use masterplan incorporating residential; flexible commercial and community floor space, in use classes A1/A2/A3/A4/A5/B1/D1 and/or D2 including, a primary school and nursery; a pedestrian / cycle bridge across the Grand Union Canal; car and cycle parking; site wide landscaping and associated works, including highway works; following the demolition of buildings and structures on the site (with the exception of the original elements of the Grade II listed Glaxo House). (EIA Application) (Departure from the Local Plan). -  Amendment includes changes to blocks 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 with associated internal layout changes providing an uplift in residential units, along with pro rata increase in cycle parking spaces; alteration of non-residential floorspace; minor external design changes; and amendments landscaping.
decision_conditions: The development permitted shall be begun before the expiration of three years from the date of the original permission ref 164694FUL (01/09/2017).

Reason: In order to ensure this brownfield site is brought forward for development as soon as practicable and to comply with the provisions of Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

| The first phase of the development (but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding) shall not commence until details of the timing of the phasing of the construction of the development hereby approved, and the extent of each phase, has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The details of the extent of each phase shall include a timeline and drawings that illustrate the following:
a)	building(s) and other structures included within each phase of development;
b)	the timing of the delivery of the site-wide energy centre;
c)	the timing and scope of the public realm works and landscaping within each phase, including the Grand Union Canal towpath improvements and bridge;
d)	the scope and timing of highway works, including the construction of bus lay-bys and bus stops;
e)	other development within each phase, including surface level car parking, externally located cycle storage; and
f)	all other infrastructure works.
The phasing of the development shall ensure that the site-wide energy centre is installed and operational before the first occupation of the 600th residential dwelling.
The phasing of the development shall proceed in accordance with the approved details, unless alternative phasing details are submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.

Reason: To ensure appropriate sequencing of development in order to provide the timely delivery of affordable housing and the site-wide energy centre; areas of public realm and landscaping relative to each phase of development; highway works and facilities for the re-routed 92 bus service; car parking and cycle storage facilities necessary to serve the relevant phase of development; the delivery of the pedestrian / cycle bridge as soon as practicable relative to the quantum of new development; and to ensure that the extent of development is acceptable from construction management, transport planning and environmental pollution perspectives.

| Development shall not commence in relation to each phase of the development until a Construction Management Plan relative to that phase has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The submission shall include the following information:

a)	details of the exclusion areas and interceptor fencing for the protection of priority and other notable species and other ecological features of the Grand Union Canal Site for Metropolitan Importance for Nature Conservation. The recommended mitigation measures to protect the environment of the Grand Union Canal set out within Chapter 7 (prepared by Ecology Solutions) of the approved Environmental Statement, shall be incorporated into each submission of the Construction Management Plan as relevant;

b)	confirmation that the enabling works include capping the discharge points and redirecting surface water to a managed system to discharge, and that there shall be no discharge to the Grand Union Canal during construction;

c)	evidence that a feasibility study has been undertaken that considers the use of the Grand Union Canal for transporting demolition waste and the delivery of freight by water; details of the number and frequency of barges to be used for such purpose; and details of the loading facilities between the site and canal to accommodate such use;

d)	confirmation that all Non-road Mobile Machinery (NRMM) used during the construction phase will comply with the NRMM Stage IIIA standards set out within the Mayor's SPG The Control of Dust and Emissions from Construction and Demolition (2014);
e)	the number of on-site construction workers and details of the transport options for them;
f)	anticipated route, anticipated number, frequency and size of construction vehicles entering / exiting the site per day;
g)	delivery times and booking systems and management of consolidated or re-timed trips;
h)	route and location of site access for construction traffic and associated signage, including provision of Banksman;

i)	details of noise, vibration and dust mitigation measures and monitoring arrangements by suitably qualified noise, vibration and air quality specialist(s).  Noise, vibration and dust mitigation measures must accord with the recommendations contained in the Mayor's SPG The Control of Dust and Emissions from Construction and Demolition (2014) and Sustainable Design and Construction SPG (2014); BS 5228 Parts 1 & 2; the Institute of Air Quality Management Guidance on the assessment of dust from demolition and construction. The findings of the dust impact assessment and the mitigation measures described at Appendix 12.7 (prepared by Air Quality Consultants Ltd) of the approved Environmental Statement shall be incorporated into the Construction Management Plan for each phase of development;
j)	details of site security and the erection and maintenance of security hoarding including decorative displays and facilities for public viewing, where appropriate;
k)	secure, off-street loading and drop-off facilities and details of the location for storage of building materials and construction debris and contractors offices;

l)	vehicle manoeuvring and turning, including swept path diagrams to demonstrate how construction vehicles would access the site and be able to turn into and emerge from the site in forward gear, including details of any temporary vehicle access points;

m)	procedures for on-site contractors to deal with complaints from members of the public, including the name and contact details for the Site Manager and / or responsible person to whom enquiries / compaints should be directed;
n)	measures to consult cyclists, disabled people and the local schools with regard  to delivery times and necessary diversions;
o)	details of all pedestrian and cyclist diversions;
p)	a commitment to be part of Considerate Constructors Scheme; and
q)	confirmation of use of TfL's Freight Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS) or similar.

Prior to the commencement of any site work on the relevant phase of development, all properties surrounding the site shall be notified in writing of the nature and duration of the works to be undertaken, and the name, telephone number and address of a responsible person to whom enquiries / complaints should be directed. These details shall also be displayed at regular intervals around the site compound.

Construction works audible beyond the boundary of the site shall only be carried out between the hours of 0800-1800hr Monday to Friday, 0800-1300hrs on Saturday, and at no other times on Sunday and public holidays.
Each phase of the development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the approved Construction Management Plan for that phase.

Reason:  To ensure appropriate mitigation measures to protect the amenity of local residents and ensure adequate highway and site safety; to reduce the impacts associated with the construction of the development; and also to ensure that protected species are appropriately safeguarded,  in accordance with policies 5.3, 5.18, 6.3, 7.14, 7.15 and 7.19 of the London Plan (2016); 1.1(e), 1.1(f) and 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration; the National Planning Policy Framework (2012), the Mayor's The Control of Dust and Emissions from Construction and Demolition SPG (2014) and Sustainable Design and Construction SPG (2014), BS 5228-1:2009 - Code of practice for noise & vibration control on construction & open sites-Part 1: Noise; The Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended) and The Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2010.

| Development shall not commence in relation to each phase of the development (but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding)  until a drainage strategy detailing any on and /or off site drainage works relative to that phase has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, in consultation with the sewerage undertaker. No discharge of foul or surface water from the site shall be accepted into the public system until the drainage works referred to in the strategy have been completed, unless otherwise agreed with the sewerage undertaker.

Reason: The development may lead to sewage flooding and details of the drainage strategy is required  to ensure that sufficient capacity is made available to cope with the new development; and in order to avoid adverse environmental impact upon the local area, in accordance with Section 11 of the NPPF; policies 5.3, 5.12, 5.13 and 5.14 of the London Plan (2016); policy 1.2(m) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012), and policy LV5.12 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013).

| Development shall not commence in relation to each phase of the development (but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding) until a detailed surface water drainage scheme relative to that phase has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The detailed surface water scheme shall be based on the drainage attenuation systems detailed within the approved Drainage Statement Issue P5 ref: GRS-GSK_MHT-J_RP_0701 dated 08/12/2016 prepared by Meinhardt; shall restrict run-off from the site to three times greenfield rates (31.5l/s) based on a site area of 2.11 Ha; attenuate a 1 in 100 year storm event with a 30% allowance for climate change; and include the following information:

a)	A clearly labelled drainage layout plan showing pipe networks and any attenuation areas or storage locations. This plan should show any pipe 'node numbers' that have been referred to in network calculations and it should also show invert and cover levels of manholes;
b)	Confirmation of the critical storm duration;

c)	Where infiltration forms part of the proposed stormwater system such as infiltration trenches and soakaways, soakage test results and test locations are to be submitted in accordance with BRE digest 365;
d)	Where on site attenuation is achieved through ponds, swales, geocellular storage or other similar methods, calculations showing the volume of these are also required;
e)	Where an outfall discharge control device is to be used such as a hydrobrake or twin orifice, this should be shown on the plan with the rate of discharge stated;
f)	Confirmation of whether surface water run-off and ground water is proposed to drain into the waterway and proposals to prevent pollution of the Grand Union Canal from the development;

g)	Calculations should demonstrate how the system operates during a 1 in 100 chance in any year critical duration storm event, including an allowance for climate change in line with the 'Planning Practice Guidance: Flood Risk and Coastal Change'. If overland flooding occurs in this event, a plan should also be submitted detailing the location of overland flow paths and the extent and depth of ponding;
h)	An exceedance route plan demonstrating methods to manage excess flows on-site from storm events in excess of 1 in 100 years (to minimise risk to people and property);
i)	A maintenance plan for the drainage system for the lifetime of the development and confirming the owners / adopters of the drainage system.

The approved surface water drainage scheme shall be implemented so that it is ready for use prior to the practical completion of the relevant phase of development, and subsequently maintained in accordance with the approved maintenance plan.

Reason: To ensure the development makes adequate provision for surface water drainage, in order to reduce the risk of flooding to the proposed development and locality, to enhance water quality and biodiversity, and to ensure the Grand Union Canal is not polluted, in accordance with the objectives of Section 11 of the NPPF; policies 5.3, 5.12, 5.13 and 5.14 of the London Plan (2016); policy 1.2(m) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012), and policy LV5.12 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013).

| No development shall commence in relation to each phase of development (including initial site clearance) until a suitable programme of monitoring of the tree protection measures, as detailed in the approved Arboricultural Implications Report ref: SJA air 16122-01c (prepared by SJA Trees) and approved Tree Protection Plans ref: SJA TPP 16122-01 NORTH Rev D, has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The monitoring programme shall include the following details:
a)	Confirmation of who shall be the lead Arboriculturist for the development.
b)	Confirmation of the Site Manager, key personnel, their key responsibilities and contact details.
c)	Details of induction procedures for all personnel in relation to Arboricultural matters.

d)	A detailed timetable of events concerning the approved tree protection plans, including; initial implementation of the protective measures, the final removal of the protective measures and any incursion/alterations to accommodate site specific construction/demolition procedures as approved in the Arboricultural Method Statement and the level of supervision required.
e)	Procedures for dealing with variations or non-approved incursions into the construction exclusion zones as detailed in the approved Arboricultural Method Statement.
f)	Proposals for when site monitoring will take place with the local Tree Officer either by site meetings or by some other pre-arranged agreement.
g)	Proposals for post development assessment of the retained and planted trees and any necessary remedial action.

Any areas of vegetation clearance and tree removal shall not be carried out during the main nesting season (March to August inclusive) unless prior checks of potential nesting are undertaken by an ecologist. Should nests be present, they will be protected until it can be confirmed that fledglings have left the nest, in accordance with Schedule 1 of the Wildlife & Countryside Act 1981.
The programme of Arboricultural monitoring for that phase shall be undertaken in full compliance with the approved details.

NB. SJA TPP 16122-01 NORTH Rev D relates to two drawings that split the site north and south, but have the same title. The drawings are located at Appendix 10.1 of Volume 2 of the approved Environmental Statement.

Reason: To secure the protection of trees, shrubs and hedges growing within or adjacent to the site which are of amenity value to the area and identified for retention, in accordance with policy 7.21 of the London Plan (2016), policy 1.1(i) of Ealing's adopted Development Strategy (2102); policy LV5.10 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); Ealing's interim SPG 9 Trees and Development Guidelines and Schedule 1 of the Wildlife & Countryside Act 1981.

| a) Each new non-residential unit within each Phase of the development shall be registered with the Building Research Establishment (BRE), and shall achieve a minimum of BREEAM Rating Very Good, based on the latest BREEAM NC Technical Guidance.

b) Within 3 months of the date of first occupation of each non-residential unit within a phase of the development, BREEAM 'Post Construction Stage' Assessment and submission of documentation confirming the BREEAM standard and measures to be implemented shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval.
The approved measures and technologies to achieve the BREEAM Very Good or higher standard shall be retained in working order thereafter.

Reason: In the interest of addressing climate change and to secure sustainable development in accordance with policies 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 5.6, 5.7 and 5.9 of the London Plan (2016), policies 1.1(k) and 1.2(f) of Ealing's adopted Development (Core) Strategy (2012), and policies 5.2 and 7A of Ealing's adopted Development Management DPD (2013).

| a) Upon the first occupation of each new residential dwelling within the approved development, the relevant dwelling shall incorporate the sustainability measures identified in the approved Energy Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Issue 5 (dated 26.08.2016) and additional supporting information (received 09/11/2016 and 20/12/2016) prepared by Meinhardt UK.

b) Upon the first occupation of each non-residential unit within the approved development, the relevant unit shall incorporate the energy and sustainability measures identified in the approved Energy Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Issue 5 (dated 26.08.2016) and additional supporting information (received 09/11/2016 and 20/12/2016) prepared by Meinhardt UK.

Reason: In the interest of addressing climate change and to secure sustainable development in accordance with policies 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 5.6, 5.7 and 5.9 of the London Plan (2016), policies LV5.2 and 7A of Ealing's adopted Development Management DPD (2013); and policies 1.1(k) and 1.2(f) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy (2012).

| Each phase of the approved development shall incorporate the mitigation measures to reduce the risk of overheating identified for that phase in the approved Energy Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Issue 5 (dated 26/08/2016) and approved additional supporting information (received 09/11/2016 and 20/12/2016) prepared by Meinhardt UK. The mitigation measures shall follow the Mayor's Cooling Hierarchy and comply with CIBSE TM49 & TM52, and in relation to approved Block 9 the Building Bulletin 101 Ventilation of School Buildings criteria.
Reason: To ensure that the development is energy efficient and takes steps to reduce the risk of overheating, in accordance with policy 5.9 of the London Plan (2016).

| a) Within three-months of the practical completion of each building in the approved development (including the residential, non-residential and primary school), Energy Performance Certificates [EPC's] and detailed modelling output reports for that building including the DER/BER and TER from the "as built stage" to confirm compliance in terms of regulated carbon dioxide emissions savings achieved through the energy efficiency measures, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.

b) Upon the completion of the final phase of the development, the overall development shall incorporate the measures to achieve an overall reduction in regulated CO2 emissions of at least 37% beyond Building Regulations Part L 2013 through the following carbon emission savings, as detailed in the approved Energy Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Issue 5 (dated 26/08/2016) and additional supporting information (received 09/11/2016 and 20/12/2016) prepared by Meinhardt UK:

i) energy saving measures to achieve annual carbon dioxide emission savings of at least 433.2 tonnes CO2 equating to 15.9% CO2 emissions reduction in regulated carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions over the compliant BR Part L 2013 base case;

ii) incorporation of two District Heating CHP units (of 357kWth and 229 kWe capacity), top-up gas boilers and thermal stores to connect all buildings within the development to supply at least 60% of the gas demand annually and achieve at least 22.36% in carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions savings over Be Lean stage;

iii) incorporation of 150kWp solar PV system to supply at least 121.6MWh of electricity annually and achieve annual carbon dioxide emission savings of at least 63.1 tonnes CO2 equating to 3.54% in carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions reduction over the Be Clean stage of the Energy Hierarchy.

A reduction in carbon dioxide emissions associated with other energy uses not covered by Building Regulations (un-regulated) should be reduced in line with approved Energy Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Issue 5 (dated 26/08/2016) and the additional supporting information (received 09/11/2016 and 20/12/2016) prepared by Meinhardt UK.

Reason:  To ensure that the development is energy efficient and reduces the need for new fossil fuel and other primary energy generation capacity, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and to minimise the impact of building emissions on local air quality in the interests of health, in accordance with policies 3.2, 5.3, 5.5, 5.6 and 7.14 of the London Plan (2016), policies 1.1(e), 1.1(j), 1.1(k) and 1.2(f) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy (2012), policies LV5.2 and 7A of Ealing's adopted Development Management DPD (2013), and the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG (2014).

| Prior to commencement of the superstructure works on the first phase of the development (but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding), the following details shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval:

a)	If relevant, the details of the temporary plant room(s), including the size and layout, size of boiler(s), siting of the container, and details of the air intake and extract flues within that phase;

Prior to the commencement of development incorporating the 500sqm site-wide energy centre (but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding), the following information shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval:
b)	a timetable for connection of all buildings to the site-wide district heating network;
c)	details of the equipment to be incorporated into the site-wide energy centre and method of how the facility shall be designed to allow future connection to an off-site district heating network;
d)	details of the 357kWth and 229 kWe DH CHP units, top-up gas boilers and thermal stores, and technical information including operational data and operational performance, costs and QI rating;
e)	specification and operation/management strategy;

f)	details of the pipe network including the size and route, flow and return temperatures, total length of the heat network in metres (flow and return) distribution and transmission, diagram route, total plant heating capacity, total heat generated, total heat supplied to premises, for the connection of all domestic and non-domestic units to the site wide district heating network;
g)	details of the Heat Interface Unit including specifications, type and efficiency;
h)	details of the feasibility of the installation of a point of external connection within the site-wide energy centre;
i)	details to demonstrate that the district heating network shall be designed in accordance with Heat Networks: Code of Practice for the UK.

The site-wide energy centre shall be ready for use in accordance with the approved timetable (sub-point b) or prior to the first occupation of the 600th residential dwelling, whichever is the sooner, and shall serve all buildings upon completion of the development, including residential and non-residential elements.
The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details.

Reason: To secure the measures set out within the approved Energy Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Issue 5 (26th August 2016) and additional supporting information (9th November & 20th December 2016) prepared by Meinhardt UK and to ensure that the single energy plant room is designed in a manner which allows for the future connection to an offsite district heat network, and to ensure that the development contributes to reducing the use of fossil fuel or other primary energy generation capacity, and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases in accordance with policies 5.3, 5.5 and 5.6 of the London Plan 2015, policies 1.1(k) and 1.2(f) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy 2012, policy LV5.2 of Ealing's Development Management DPD, and the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG.

| Sound insulation measures shall be provided to all habitable rooms located with a faade affected by noise emanating from Greenford Road, Oldfield Lane North and the industrial uses located to the south of the Grand Union Canal such that the measures comply with the criteria specified at Section 4, Part B (Criteria for adequate protection for new buildings) of Ealing's interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration. The sound insulation measures shall be incorporated into the external building fabric, acoustically treated glazing, and other means of ventilation provided (precluding natural ventilation from open windows).
The sound mitigation measures shall be implemented prior to the first occupation of any residential units in the relevant part of the development and retained thereafter.

Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the apartment buildings adjoining locations identified as exceeding accepted residential noise levels, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan (2016); policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), and Ealing's interim SPG10: Noise and Vibration.

| In respect of each approved residential Block, sound limiting insulation for all divisions (walls and / or floors) separating the approved non-residential uses and internal car parking areas from the residential dwellings located above these areas in that Block, to achieve at least +5dB above the Building Regulations Approved Document E standard (Dwelling houses and flats) for airborne sound insulation and -5dB for impact sound insulation, shall be provided prior to the first occupation of the new dwellings in that Block. The sound limiting insulation shall be retained thereafter.

Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the residential units located above the approved non-residential units and car parking areas, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan (2016); policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), and Ealing's interim SPG10: Noise and Vibration.

| Prior to the first occupation of each non-residential unit in that Block that during its operational use would incorporate amplified sound, details to demonstrate that the sound reduction index of the separating party floor/ceiling or walls, Rw, would achieve the following criteria with windows shut and other means of ventilation provided, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority:

a) The background L90,15min linear noise level in any one third octave band from 50Hz to 160 Hz, and also the overall Linear L90 level, as previously measured inside a habitable room of the nearest affected premises with windows closed, shall not be increased when the amplified music or speech is played and the measurement is repeated at the same position, using L90 linear over any 5 minute period with the background and source operating together; and
The composite sound reduction index of the building envelope, Rw, would achieve the following criteria with windows shut and other means of ventilation provided:

b) The background L90,15min linear noise level in any one third octave band from 50Hz to 160 Hz, and also the overall Linear L90 level, as previously measured at 1 m from the nearest faade of the nearest affected premises, shall not be increased when the amplified music or speech is played and the measurement is repeated in the same position, using L90 linear over any 5 minute period with the background and source operating together.
The approved details shall be installed prior to the first occupation of the relevant part of such non-residential units in that Block.

Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the residential units located above the approved non-residential units, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan (2016); policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), and Ealing's interim SPG10: Noise and Vibration.

| Within three-months of the commencement of the phase of the development to provide the site-wide energy centre, but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding), the details of the acoustic treatment of the extract flues and air intake vents, to demonstrate the mitigation of noise and vibration impacts on buildings, amenity spaces and adjacent uses, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The flues and vents shall be provided in accordance with the approved details prior to the first use of the site-wide energy centre, and the approved acoustic treatment retained in working order in perpetuity.

The extract flues and air intake vents serving the site-wide energy centre, including the boilers, CHP plant and plant room ventilation system, shall be provided in accordance with the approved details shown on drawing ref: GRS-GSK_MHT-N_XX-XX_SK_5002 P2 and GRS-GSK_HTA-L_SK170124. Any change to the details of these matters shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the phase of commencement of the development to provide the site-wide energy centre (but excluding site survey and ground investigation works, utility diversions, demolition, site clearance works, remediation of any contamination, preliminary infrastructure works, site preparation works, any archaeological and investigations and erection of temporary boundary fencing or hoarding).

Reason: To ensure that the design and location of flues and vents do not detract from the amenity and recreation spaces within the site and the canalside environment, and to ensure that the flues and vents are adequately acoustically treated in order to provide a satisfactory standard of amenity for the intended use of the site, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan 2015; policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD, and Ealing's interim SPG10: Noise and Vibration.

| The rating noise level emitted from any proposed site plant and machinery, including air handling units, boilers, passenger lifts, and mechanical ventilation of car parking areas, as assessed under BS4142: 1997, shall be lower than the existing background noise level by at least 10 dBA of the existing background level (LA90 15min) during the relevant periods of operation. The noise limiting mitigation measures shall be retained in working order thereafter.

Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the buildings within the site, and sensitive receptors adjoining the site, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan 2015; policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD, and Ealing's interim SPG10: Noise and Vibration.
| Deliveries to and collections from the approved non-residential units shall only be permitted between the hours of 07:00 and 20:00 o
